;北京已确认欧盟外交事务负责人何塞普·博雷尔将于今年秋季访华，并外交部长王毅提供了两次推迟的访问的更多细节——首先是因为他感染了Covid-19，其次是时任外交部长秦刚突然缺席。

;

;外交部长王毅在周日的电话中告诉博雷尔表示，“中方欢迎”欧盟外交官及其代表团“今年秋季访问并进行战略对话，通过广泛深入的交流为（双边）领导人峰会做好准备”。

;

;年度战略对话是这是欧盟-中国峰会的必要前奏，峰会预计在今年年底前举行。

;

;根据中国外交部的消息，博雷尔表示，“我期待访问中国并开展”

;

;“我们期待这次[领导人]峰会，这将从战略上引领中欧关系和双边合作的方向。”

;

;据中国外交部称，乌克兰战争和尼日尔军事政变也是两人讨论的问题之一。

;

;《南华早报》上个月报道称，博雷尔在雅加达举行的东盟会议期间会见王后，“暂时”同意于 10 月访问中国。

;

;王代表他的前任，据说前任因健康原因无法出席原因。经过数周的猜测，秦在两周前被解除了这一职务。

;

;在与博雷尔的电话中，王重申了秦对更密切的中欧关系的呼吁——在来自中国的压力越来越大的情况下，这是中国外交政策的重点。王表示，中国正在寻求更多“对话机制”，以弥补疫情期间北京和布鲁塞尔之间交流减少的情况，并“注入新的力量”。

;

;欧盟外交事务负责人何塞普·博雷尔(Josep Borrell)着眼于10月访华

;

;在其任期内，秦多次访问欧洲，游说反对欧盟“脱欧”。他警告称，这一战略可能会导致欧洲大陆的“去中国化”。

;

;虽然双方关系取得了进展，法国和德国等主要欧盟贸易伙伴领导人访问了北京，但欧盟成员国上个月重申了减少对中国的严重依赖和脆弱性的计划，特别是在供应链方面。

;

;6 月，柏林发布了首份中国战略，其中包括降低德国关系风险的意图

;

;德国新的对华战略转向去风险化

;

;根据之前的报道，博雷尔打算在 7 月份取消任期期间与北京就“所有问题”进行接触访问的内容包括“伙伴关系”、“竞争”和“系统性竞争”。

;

;他还预计将与秦和其他高级官员讨论“战略问题”，包括人权和俄罗斯入侵乌克兰。

;

;博雷尔在 7 月份接受彭博社采访时表示，他“完全保证”推迟的会议将在今年下一次中欧峰会之前举行，目标是在秋季访问中国.

; Mon, 07 Aug 2023 13:50:04 +0800 Not just Trump: these leaders also got into legal troublehttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/article/3230202/not-just-trump-these-leaders-also-got-legal-trouble?utm_source=rss_feed

;美国前总统唐纳德·特朗普上周出现在华盛顿法庭，进行他的第三次审判离任后受到刑事指控，这在美国是史无前例的事件，但却使该国与世界其他地区保持一致。

;

;尽管特朗普的盟友抗议称，起诉政客是不发达“香蕉”的标志共和国”，这种情况也发生在法国和德国等先进民主国家。看一下。

;

;

;

;

;

;萨科齐于 2021 年被判处一年监禁，原因是帮助一名地方法官获得一份享有盛誉的工作，以换取有关以下信息的信息法律调查。尽管这位保守党领袖上诉失败，但判决尚未执行。在另一起案件中，萨科齐因在 2012 年竞选连任失败中故意违反竞选财务规则而被判有罪。他被判处一年徒刑，但在上诉期间被缓刑。

;

;

;

;2011 年，希拉克成为现代第一位被定罪的法国国家元首。离任后犯罪。这位已故中右翼领导人因病重而无法出庭，被判在担任首都市长期间滥用巴黎市资金罪，并被判处两年缓刑。

;

;;

;保守派集团在 1998 年选举中击败社会民主党后不久，科尔就面临腐败和非法政党融资的指控。检察官对科尔进行了一年多的调查，但最终于 2001 年决定撤销此案，条件是这位前总理必须缴纳高额罚款，他也确实这么做了。

;

;

;

;贝卢斯科尼据我自己计算，在他的政治生涯中，他面临着 100 多项与税务欺诈、贿赂和非法性行为等指控有关的调查和审判。意大利战后任期最长的总理几十年来一直被无罪释放，但在 2013 年税务欺诈定罪被搁置后，他失去了参议院席位，并被禁止担任公职。一如既往，他仍然在 2022 年实现了某种程度的东山再起，当时他被允许再次竞选公职并再次当选议会议员。

;

;

;

;

;

;以色列首位接受审判的现任总理内塔尼亚胡面临贿赂、欺诈和失信指控。检察官指控该国任职时间最长的总理滥用职权，非法接受——有时甚至要求——亿万富翁朋友提供的优质葡萄酒和昂贵的雪茄。他们还认为，他为了赢得媒体的好评而破坏了办公室的诚信。内塔尼亚胡否认有任何不当行为。

;

;

;

;

;

;祖马因拒绝在司法委员会作证而于 2021 年因藐视法庭被判处 15 个月监禁在他九年的统治期间对国家腐败进行调查。他在监狱服刑几个月后获得保外就医。祖马目前正在接受审判，被指控接受与 1999 年军火交易有关的贿赂。

;

;

;

;巴博于 2011 年底被国际刑事法院指控犯有反人类罪。巴博在海牙度过了数年的时光，之后法院于 2019 年宣判他无罪，并于 2021 年维持原判。巴博还因在 2011 年选举后冲突期间闯入西非中央银行分支机构而被定罪，面临 20 年监禁。 2022 年，他被现任科特迪瓦总统阿拉萨内·瓦塔拉赦免。

;

;

;

;Compaore 于 2022 年因谋杀托马斯·桑卡拉而被定罪，托马斯·桑卡拉是非洲标志性领导人，于 35 年前在政变中身亡。 。他被判处终身监禁。孔波雷目前流亡在科特迪瓦。

;

;

;

;孔德于 2021 年政变中被推翻，被指控犯有谋杀、绑架、性暴力和强迫失踪事件。这些指控与 2020 年孔德第三次连任颇受争议后发生的致命选举暴力事件有关。他的审判尚未开始。

;

;

;

;阿卜杜勒-阿齐兹于 2009 年至 2019 年统治这个北非国家，目前正在接受审判，面临滥用职权、兜售影响力、洗钱和资产非法增加。他的辩护律师表示，这些指控是政治性的，旨在损害他的声誉。

;

;

;

;卡马被指控非法持有枪支，州检察官称这些罪行发生在他的十年期间- 2018 年结束的长期总统任期。卡马目前身在邻国南非，面临引渡程序。

;

;

;

;

;

;这位前板球明星刚刚被捕并因在执政期间隐匿出售国礼所得罪名被判三年徒刑。自去年 4 月被赶下台以来，汗已处理了 170 多起法律案件。

;

;这些案件的范围从腐败和谋杀到恐怖主义和暴力指控。他还在 5 月份的其中一起案件中被短暂逮捕，这一事态发展引发了巴基斯坦各地的暴力事件以及对领导人政党的镇压。

;

;

;

;纳吉布因被控以下罪名接受审判：涉嫌滥用 1MDB 的 23 亿林吉特（5.08 亿美元）资金进行洗钱和滥用权力，该国家投资基金成为丑闻的焦点，在亚洲、美国和欧洲引发了多项调查。

;

;法庭听证会将于 8 月 14 日恢复。他还因与 1MDB 前子公司 SRC International 有关的另一项腐败定罪而被判 12 年监禁。他是第一位因腐败被定罪并入狱的前马来西亚领导人。

;

;

;

;他信在 2006 年军事政变中被赶下台，15 年前逃离泰国，以避免腐败指控。出于政治动机。他在四起贪污案件中被缺席判有罪，罪名包括非法隐瞒自己创办的一家电信公司的股份，以及因一家国有银行向缅甸政府提供的贷款而产生利益冲突。

;

;他信将面临距离他返回泰国已有 10 年之久，原定于 8 月 10 日返回泰国，但被推迟到当月晚些时候。

;

;

;

;埃斯特拉达于 2000 年因贿赂和腐败指控而被弹劾，但2001 年初，一场大规模起义导致他辞职，参议院对他的审判被缩短。随后，他因涉嫌收受回扣而被指控犯有掠夺罪，并于 2007 年被判有罪。

;

;定罪后仅几个月，他就被其继任者格洛丽亚·马卡帕加尔·阿罗约 (Gloria Macapagal Arroyo) 赦免了阿罗约，阿罗约本人也面临掠夺指控，后来被最高法院宣判无罪。

;

;

;

;自 20 世纪 80 年代末实现完全民主以来，几乎每个南方国家韩国总统卸任后深陷法律麻烦。卢武铉因在总统期间接受数亿美元的行贿基金而被判处 22.5 年监禁。

;

;李在镕因涉及其兄弟汽车零部件公司的腐败计划而被判处 17 年监禁。朴槿惠因腐败被弹劾、免职并被判处 20 多年监禁。所有人都被继任者赦免。

;

;

;

;曾荫权于 2017 年因任职不当行为被判处 20 个月监禁，成为香港金融中心第一位被定罪的前领导人。在与向市政府申请广播许可证的房东协商豪华公寓租金时，未能披露利益冲突。服刑 12 个月后，他因技术原因被无罪释放。

;

;

;

;

;

;1973 年至 1990 年间统治该国的陆军将军1998年因种族灭绝和恐怖主义罪名在伦敦被捕。 2000 年，他因健康原因被释放，并返回智利，六年后，他在那里被起诉并被勒令软禁。

;

;

;

;科雷亚在对其参与的调查期间逃往比利时。巴西建筑集团 Odebrecht 承认向整个非洲大陆的公职人员行贿。他被缺席定罪并被判处八年监禁，但正在策划通过本月的提前选举让他的政党重新掌权。

;

;

;

;博尔索纳罗，即所谓的“特朗普”巴西法院发现，“热带地区的总统”滥用职权，散布有关该国电子投票系统的错误信息，以维持权力，因此在 2030 年之前不得竞选公职。

;

;5 月，警方突击搜查了他的家，寻找伪造的新冠疫苗接种卡，据称助手和家人曾用这些卡来逃避旅行限制。他还因泄露机密信息而接受调查。

;

;

;

;阿尔贝托·藤森 (Alberto Fujimori) 被判侵犯人权（包括政府行刑队绑架和谋杀）、贿赂和贪污罪。他曾两次被赦免，两次赦免又被推翻。亚历杭德罗·托莱多 (Alejandro Toledo) 于 4 月被从美国引渡到秘鲁，接受腐败和洗钱指控的审判。

;

;艾伦·加西亚 (Alan Garcia) 也卷入了同一起腐败丑闻，但在警察赶到时开枪自杀身亡。逮捕他。奥兰塔·乌马拉 (Ollanta Humala) 正在等待与同一调查相关的腐败指控的审判。佩德罗·巴勃罗·库琴斯基 (Pedro Pablo Kuczynski) 在被免职之前就被弹劾并辞职；他现在在监狱等待审判。

;

;最后一位民选总统佩德罗·卡斯蒂略(Pedro Castillo)基本上避免了导致其前任倒台的腐败丑闻，但与国会进行了斗争，国会曾三度试图弹劾他。当他试图解散国会时，他因煽动叛乱和叛国罪而遭到弹劾并被捕。

;

;

;

;

;

;尼克松于 1974 年辞职，即众议院司法委员会成立 10 天后委员会通过了可能导致他免职的弹劾条款。这些文章指控他妨碍司法、滥用权力和藐视国会，因为他试图掩盖对手位于水门大楼的总部被盗窃的事件——这一丑闻将在未来的政治丑闻中加上“-gate”后缀。副总统杰拉尔德·福特就任总统，后来赦免了尼克松可能犯下的任何罪行。

;

;

;

;克林顿于 1998 年因两篇指控他妨碍司法公正的文章而遭到弹劾。因与实习生莫妮卡·莱温斯基的恋情而起的誓言。参议院未能达到罢免他所需的三分之二票数。 2001年卸任后，最高法院吊销了他的律师执照，他在被完全取消律师执业资格之前辞职。

;

;

;

;特朗普遇到的法律问题比所有美国总统都多。他的43位前任加起来。众议院两次弹劾他，一次是指控他寻求乌克兰的帮助来影响 2020 年总统选举，另一次是在 2021 年 1 月 6 日美国国会大厦袭击事件后。每次他都被参议院宣告无罪。

;

;此后，他在担任总统之前、之后和期间三度因犯罪行为被起诉：在 2016 年大选前向色情女演员支付封口费，在卸任后不当处理机密信息 - 而现在，因在 2020 年投票下台后阻碍权力和平移交。

;

;如果因更严重的指控而被定罪，他可能会在监狱中度过余生，但定罪并不能阻止他如果他明年当选总统，他将在 2025 年上任。

;洪马奈作为柬埔寨新领导人的提名于周一获得该国国王的批准。这位 45 岁的领导人实际上是由统治近四十年的父亲授予的这一职位。

;

;在 7 月的选举中取得压倒性胜利后几天，洪森 — — 世界上任职时间最长的领导人之一 — —宣布他将辞去总理职务，并将权力移交给他的长子。

;

;主要反对党挑战者烛光党因技术细节被禁止参选后，这次民意调查被广泛谴责为一场骗局。执政的柬埔寨人民党在 125 名议员的下议院赢得了除 5 个席位之外的所有席位。

;

;周一，应洪森的要求，诺罗敦·西哈莫尼国王发布了一项皇家法令，声明他“任命洪森博士”马奈出任柬埔寨王国首相，接受议会第七次授权”。

;

;支持这位受过西方教育的陆军将军的法令在他父亲的 Telegram 频道上分享，这标志着柬埔寨王国的统治即将结束。这位前红色高棉游击队员掌管了一个从数十年的战争和贫困中恢复过来的国家近四十年。

;

;然而，要正式成为该国的下一任领导人，洪马奈和他的内阁必须赢得信任投票议会预计将于本月晚些时候召开。

;

;即将上任的政府将迎来一批年轻的部长，其中一些将接替其父辈空出的职位。

;

;同时坚称他不会干涉儿子的事务洪森还向柬埔寨人民承诺，他将继续主宰国家政治。

;

;柬埔寨洪森在任职 38 年后辞去首相职务

;

;洪森于 1985 年上台，森帮助这个饱受内战和种族灭绝蹂躏的国家实现现代化，尽管批评者称他的统治也带来了环境破坏、根深蒂固的腐败和消灭几乎所有政治对手的特点。

;

;美国、联合国和”他在任内去世。

;

;他还警告说，如果洪马奈的生命受到严重威胁，他将重新担任首相。

;

;尽管多年来一直在为这一职位做好准备，但洪马奈的长子分析人士称，柬埔寨的铁腕统治者在政治舞台上仍未经受考验。

;

;尽管洪马奈在英国和美国接受过教育，但人们很少期望他会比他的父亲走上一条更加自由的道路。< /p>;

;作为执政党强大的常设委员会成员，他自 2018 年起担任柬埔寨皇家陆军司令。

;

;洪马内还会见了一些世界领导人，包括中国国家主席习近平、柬埔寨国家主席习近平主要盟友和重要捐助者。

;

;被洪森政权压制后，著名柬埔寨诗人现在成为面条车上的奴隶

;

;下台后，洪森将于明年初成为参议院议长国王在海外时担任代理国家元首。

;

;在海外期间，洪马奈在美国获得了经济学硕士学位，在英国获得了经济学博士学位。他也是美国著名的西点军校的毕业生。

;

;洪马奈很少谈及他对国家的愿景。他在选举中赢得了首都金边的一个席位。

;

;Two years ago, Dubai's skyscraper-studded skyline welcomed a Ferris wheel touted as the world's largest, but it mysteriously stopped turning just months after opening.

;

;The much-touted Ain Dubai (Dubai Eye) was designed as a tourist-luring landmark in the United Arab Emirates' glam-hub, which is home to the world's tallest building.

;

;But now it stands idle for undisclosed reasons, its extravagant light fixtures the only parts seemingly still working.

;

;“Ain Dubai remains closed until further notice,” says an official website for the attraction.

;

;“We continue to rigorously work on completing the enhancement works that have been taking place over the past months.”

;

;The wheel was supposed to close for just a month but its reopening has since been postponed indefinitely.

;

;Inside Dubai's US$204 million 'Marble Mansion' – the UAE's most expensive home

;

;Those behind the project inaugurated in 2021 have failed to reply to enquiries.

;

;At restaurants, shops and cafes built around the attraction, employees remain sceptical that the structure, which took around six years to build, will ever turn again.

;

;“Last year they promised us that in winter it will be open, even now, they are saying that in (the coming) winter it will be open again,” said one employee at a nearby shop.

;

;“But we're not sure … it will,” said the man who asked to remain anonymous due to fear of reprisal.

;

;The Dubai Eye, built by a consortium of international companies, is located in Bluewaters – a man-made island designed as a retail, residential and entertainment hub.

;

;For more than a year, the main entrance to the attraction has remained closed and ticket booths abandoned. Only a slow trickle of tourists visit the site, snapping pictures of LED lights mounted on its exterior.

;

;In a city filled with record-breaking landmarks, the Dubai Eye stands at a height of 250 metres (825 feet), each of its legs the length of 15 London buses, according to Dubai's tourism department.

;

;Nearly twice as tall as the London Eye, it is the largest of its kind in the world.

;

;Its 48 passenger cabins, all of them air-conditioned, can carry around 1,750 passengers on a single ride.

;

;Ticket prices range between 100 dirhams (about US$27) and 4,700 dirhams (about $1,280), with luxury passes and private cabins on offer.

;

;With no official explanation, rumours are rife on the Ferris wheel's apparent technical issues, especially among employees at Bluewaters.

;

;They all spoke on condition of anonymity, fearing repercussions from authorities or their employers.

;

;Plot of sand on Dubai's luxury Jumeirah Bay Island fetches record US$34 million

;

;“This is a man-made island. I heard that (the wheel) is heavier than the island itself, that's why it is very dangerous,” said a waiter at a nearby restaurant, adding that it had been noisy during its few months of operation.

;

;“Now … it's only for show, just for the lighting and that's it”.

;

;The giant wheel, made of more steel than the Eiffel Tower, features prominently on the list of Dubai's top tourist attractions.

;

;They include the Dubai Frame monument and Burj Khalifa, the world's tallest building.

;

;Patrick Clawson, research director at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy, said official silence on the Ferris wheel suggested a complicated problem.

;

;UAE authorities are generally “quick to provide information if they” have a solution, he said.

;

;But with the Dubai Eye, “whatever the problem, the authorities are not confident they have a solution”.

;The World Directory of Modern Military Warships (WDMMW) has ranked the strongest navies in the world, covering 36 nations.

;

;The ranking looked at the total number of warships and submarines, alongside factors such as fleet age, logistical support, and attack and defence capabilities.

;

;It also looked at the balance of each force: how many different types of assets they have, and if they are concentrating their assets in one area. It included most ships but left out smaller craft, survey ships, and historical ceremonial vessels.

;

;The ranking distinguished between several classes of combat ship – listing the relatively small corvette and frigate types as well as larger destroyers and cruisers.

;

;Each navy was given a final “True Value Rating” to measure them against one another. Here's how the top 25 countries stack up:

;

;

;

;The 46 total units in Brazil's active naval inventory are one helicopter carrier, seven submarines, six frigate warships, two corvettes, five mine/countermine warfare ships, 22 offshore patrol vessels, and three amphibious assault vessels, according to the WDMMW.

;

;It has no destroyers or cruisers.

;

;It said Brazil's naval force balance is “average” and its median hull age is 30.3 years.

;

;The WDMMW gave Brazil's navy a True Value Rating of 39.9.

;

;

;

;The WDMMW gave Singapore's navy a True Value Rating of 43.2.

;

;It had 37 total units in its active naval inventory as of November 2022, made up of five submarines, six frigates, six corvettes, four mine/countermine warfare ships, 12 offshore patrol vessels, and amphibious assault vessels.

;

;It has no aircraft carriers, destroyers, or cruisers.

;

;The WDMMW listed its force balance as “average” and said its median hull age is 19.2 years.

;

;

;

;The WDMMW gave Canada's navy a True Value Rating of 43.7.

;

;Canada has four submarines, 12 frigates, and 21 offshore patrol vessels, making up its 37 active units as of December 2021. The nation has the world's largest coastline.

;

;The WDMMW noted that Canada “lacks a dedicated aircraft carrier fleet” and also cited its lack of a helicopter force of amphibious assault capabilities.

;

;Canada also has no destroyer warships, corvette warships, cruiser warships, or mine/countermine warfare ships.

;

;Canada's median hull age is a relatively young 16.8, and WDMMW described its naval force balance as “fair.”

;

;

;

;Greece has 11 submarines, 3 frigates, three mine/countermine warfare ships and 36 offshore patrol vessels, making up its 63 active units as of November 2022, according to the WDMMW.

;

;It noted that Greece has put its focus on the offshore vessels, with that fleet “making up over half of all fighting strength”.

;

;The balance makes sense for the Mediterranean nation, which has some 6,000 islands.

;

;The WDMMW described the rest of the Greece's fleet as “an ageing fleet of submarines and frigates for the most part”.

;

;Greece has no destroyers, corvettes, cruisers, or amphibious assault vessels.

;

;The WDMMW said the navy's force balance is “fair” and median hull age is 27.5 years.

;

;It gave Greece's navy a True Value Rating of 47.2.

;

;

;

;Thailand had 86 total units in its active naval inventory as of January 2023.

;

;They were one helicopter carrier, four destroyers, seven frigates, six corvettes, five mine/countermine warfare ships, 51 offshore patrol vessels, and 12 amphibious assault vessels.

;

;It has no submarines, with the WDMMW describing it as “a surface force built primarily around local and regional defence”.

;

;It noted Thailand's long coastline and near neighbours of Myanmar, Laos, Vietnam, Cambodia, and Malaysia.

;

;The WDMMW noted that Thailand is working with China to acquire submarines. It also has no cruisers.

;

;The Thai navy has a median hull age of 25.6 years and had an “average” force balance, the WDMMW said.

;

;The WDMMW gave Thailand's navy a True Value Rating of 47.6.

;

;

;

;The WDMMW gave Australia's navy a True Value Rating of 48.9.

;

;It said Australia has a young median hull age, at 16.2 years, and that its naval force balance is “average”.

;

;Its 36 active units as of October 2022 were six submarines, three destroyers, eight frigates, four mine/countermine warfare ships, 12 offshore patrol vessels, and 12 amphibious assault vessels.

;

;It has no corvettes, cruisers, or aircraft carriers.

;

;The WDMMW noted that the navy's “bulk of strength” comes from its offshore patrol vessel force, “which makes up more than a quarter of all available strength”.

;

;

;

;The WDMMW gave Iran's navy, with its 66 total active units as of November 2022, a True Value Rating of 50.3.

;The US government lab that last year reached a long-sought milestone in nuclear fusion – achieving a controlled reaction that yielded more energy than it took to produce – has repeated the achievement, after months of near-misses.

;

;Being able to reproduce the December 5 breakthrough may bring the world one step closer to using fusion, which powers the stars, as an abundant source of clean energy. But that future likely remains years off, if it happens at all.

;

;The Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory near San Francisco conducted a series of tests this spring and summer that didn't quite achieve “ignition”, the point at which energy output from the experiment exceeds the amount pouring in.

;

;Each test involves firing the world's most powerful laser at a tiny diamond capsule filed with hydrogen, compressing the fuel and triggering the reaction. One experiment in June achieved breakeven, with the same amount of energy coming out as went in.

;

;They finally reached ignition again last week, according to a statement Sunday from the lab. The news was first reported by the Financial Times.

;

;“In an experiment conducted on July 30, we repeated ignition,” the statement read. “对这些结果的分析正在进行中。 As is our standard practice, we plan on reporting those results at upcoming scientific conferences and in peer-reviewed publications.”

;

;Unlike fission, the process used in current nuclear power plants, fusion involves smashing atoms together instead of splitting them apart.

;

;It theoretically can supply carbon-free energy without long-lasting radioactive waste. But generations of scientists have struggled to master it in a controlled reaction, even though it has been the power source of nuclear weapons for decades.

;

;In addition to the process used by the Livermore lab, known as inertial confinement, researchers are still trying to achieve ignition using high-powered magnets to contain a fusion reaction within a doughnut-shaped ring of plasma. And turning either approach into a steadily running power plant presents its own challenges.

;Japan labelled China its “greatest strategic challenge” in a recent defence white paper, and though analysts say Tokyo's hardening position is “clearly a concern for Southeast Asia” they note that “behind closed doors” regional elites likely understand the approach.

;

;The challenge posed by China is “unprecedented”, Japan said in the annual paper released on July 28, pointing to Beijing's external stance, military activities and other acts that it said had become a serious concern. In response, Chinese defence ministry spokesman Tan Kefei slammed the “erroneous” paper, saying Tokyo had “crudely” interfered in Beijing's internal affairs and stirred regional tensions.

;

;Japan's white paper also underscored the “imminent threat” posed by North Korea and noted that Russia's military activities in the region, alongside its strategic coordination with China, were of “strong security concern”.

;

;“The region knows that Japan's strategic posture toward China is getting firmer than before, and this is clearly a concern for Southeast Asia,” said Kei Koga, an associate professor of public policy and global affairs at Singapore's Nanyang Technological University.

;

;Koga said Japan had been closely communicating with member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations on its defence and security posture and was looking to mitigate any confrontation through multilateral engagement.

;

;This approach has spanned discussions at the Asean Regional Forum, as well as other Asean-led gatherings that included China, South Korea, Australia, India, New Zealand, Russia and the United States as dialogue partners, he said.

;

;“Tokyo is mindful of the negative repercussions of expanding its security role in the region too fast,” said Bhubhindar Singh, an associate professor at the S. Rajaratnam School of International Studies (RSIS) in Singapore whose main research focus is Japan's security policy.

;

;Singh said Southeast Asian states had not raised fresh concerns about Tokyo's latest white paper as it expressed similar views in the National Security Strategy and National Defence Strategy documents it released in December.

;

;China hits out at Japan's 'erroneous' defence white paper

;

;Purnendra Jain, an emeritus professor at the University of Adelaide's department of Asian studies, said Southeast Asian nations would continue to view China through their own strategic prism and assess their outlook independently.

;

;“They are hesitant to make a choice between China and Japan; indeed, they want to interact with and engage both,” Jain said.

;

;Joshua Bernard Espeña, a resident fellow at the International Development and Security Cooperation think tank in Manila, said that while Southeast Asian nations were concerned with how Japan was reacting militarily to China's rise, “behind closed doors”, regional elites likely understood Tokyo's approach.

;

;“[They have] experiences with China's maritime expansion,” Espeña said, referring to the skirmishes that countries such as Vietnam and the Philippines have had with Chinese vessels in the disputed South China Sea.

;

;In the 2023 State of Southeast Asia Survey by Singapore's ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute, Japan emerged as the most trusted major power in the region, mainly due to its decades of development aid and infrastructure investment.

;

;

;

;By 2027, Japan aims to double its defence spending to about 2 per cent of its gross domestic product – or 43 trillion yen (US$303.2 billion) over five years – a sharp increase from the 17.2 trillion yen it spent in the 2019 to 2023 period.

;

;The new spending target is in line with Nato's standard and is set to increase Japan's annual budget to about 10 trillion yen, the world's third-largest after the United States and China.

;

;Jain said that Japan's increased military spending had already begun and could accelerate over the next four years – though the country's declining population and shrinking revenue base may prove a challenge.

;

;Tokyo earlier said long-range counterstrike capabilities were key to deterring any attacks on Japan while defending against incoming missiles.

;

;“This may lead to the 'security dilemma' in the region, [or] one state's increasing military strength leading other states to increase their military strength,” Jain said, adding that the “the game-changer in Japan's threat perception” was the war in Ukraine.

;

;He said that Beijing and Moscow's 'no-limits' partnership had “unsettled Japanese strategists much more than before”, noting the less hawkish approach to defence and security Japan had taken under Prime Minister Fumio Kishida his predecessor Shinzo Abe.

;

;Japan's defence white paper was “not a cause but a symptom of the strategic situation”, Koga said.

;

;As US-China ties fray, expect more shows of Beijing-North Korea unity: analysts

;

;RSIS' Singh added that apart from China, Japan's adverse reading of the strategic environment was also related to North Korea's attempts at strengthening its nuclear and ballistic missile programmes.

;

;“This reading of the environment has and will shape Japan's security policy evolution and growing role in shaping the balance of power in the region,” Singh said.

;

;Late last month, North Korea fired two ballistic missiles into the sea off its east coast, hours after a US nuclear-powered submarine arrived at a naval base in South Korea.

;

;Since the start of 2022, North Korea has test-fired around 100 missiles. In July, supreme leader Kim Jong-un personally oversaw the firing of the country's newest intercontinental ballistic missile, the solid-fuel Hwasong-18.
